justification: The text notes that "Barratt Impulsivity scores (BIS-11; Patton et al., 1995)" are examined in relation to other variables, showing BIS-11 is the instrument used to obtain impulsivity scores.
"To measure impulsivity, we used the Short Version of the UPPS-P Impulsive Behavior scale â€¦ (S-UPPS-P)."
"Negative Urgency, a subscale of the UPPS scale, captures tendencies to respond with rash speech and behavior in the face of negative emotion."
"A separate subscale of the UPPS, Positive Urgency, covering tendencies to respond rashly to positive emotion states, was identified more recently."
The article lists "lack of Perseverance" as one of the "self-rated forms of impulsivity" that are captured by specific UPPS subscales.
It states that Negative Urgency is separable from other forms "such as lack of Premeditation," indicating this facet is assessed with its own UPPS subscale.
The same sentence groups "Sensation-seeking" with other UPPS facets, implying it is measured via the dedicated UPPS subscale.
"Performance is lower on reversal learning tasks among those with high impulsivity, as measured using the I7 (Franken et al., 2008)."
The authors mention "the digit span task" among working-memory tasks used to study links with impulsivity, treating it as a working-memory measure.
They refer to "the N-back task (Mueller et al., 2017; Whitney et al., 2004; Zeng et al., 2013)" as one of the working-memory tasks examined.
The article lists "the CANTAB test of spatial working memory (Berlin et al., 2005; Manning et al., 2013)" among measures of working memory.
It includes "the O-Span task (Lempert & Pizzagalli, 2010)" in a series of working-memory assessments.
Lower working memory performance links are discussed using "the Letter-number Sequence task (Rochat et al., 2013)," indicating the task serves as a working-memory measure.
